title: Kenya: Soda Ash Mining in Magadi Threatened By Soil Erosion Into the Lake
text:
Zimbabwe: Zim Vies for Diamond Body Chairmanship 
"When the soda ash is compromised in quality then we have to give a differential in price," the company's managing director, Jack Muchira Mbui explained. 
"We have to deduct a certain percentage on the value depending on how low the total alkalinity of soda ash has dropped from the internationally certified standards, which currently stands at 99 per cent. 
"Currently the alkalinity levels of the soda ash being produced at Magadi has been declining steadily and now stands at 95 per cent down from 97 per cent," he said. 
He added: "Magadi operates in a very quality conscious industry, as 90 per cent of the soda ash is exported to international manufacturers of glassware who are very specific about the amount of impurities they can allow in their stocks as it affects the quality of glass they make." 
COMPENSATE UNHAPPY CUSTOMERS 
The company has already been forced to compensate discontented customers, he said, causing millions of losses for the company. 
He said more resources were being incurred in the production processes in terms of energy costs as they try to clean the impurities. 
"But even then, some of them are insoluble that we can't get them out and that is where the major problem is." 
"We will have to incur at least Sh200 million each to shift the two dredge systems that we have on the southern part of the lake, which is badly affected by the soils. There are already trees growing there," he noted. 
The siltation, which is said to have first been noticed in 2005, has already rendered 14 square kilometres of the minable lake's surface inoperable. 
"Siltation has been affecting the formation of trona, which naturally regenerates with volcanic activities over a period of about five years to be mined as soda ash now the section we can mine has slowly been shrinking as a result of deposited soils settling and mixing with the trona as it forms," said the firm's geologist, George Otiende, during a visit of the lake on Monday. 
According to him the soils, are being deposited at the rate of 8000 tonnes per hour during flash floods. 
He said the soils were emanating from Suswa and Nairagie Enkare in Narok County, about 100 kilometres away. 
Dust blows in a whirlwind on a portion of Lake Magadi that has been undergoing siltation over time. PHOTO | PAULINE KAIRU | NATION MEDIA GROUP 
SOIL EROSION 
On area leaders including Governor David Nkedianye and Kajiado West MP Moses Ole Sakuda blamed soil erosion as a result of deforestation and poor farming practices. 
They said they would mobilise residents to plant trees and train them on good farming practices. 
Mr Mbui said the situation had created an uncertain future for the nation's prized soda ash mining industry as it faced competition from other producers inducing China and America. 
The damage, it is feared, will not only be to the miner who is also a leading producer of animal and industrial salt, but is considered a threat to an entire ecological system of the lake. 
This includes the flamingos that use the lake as a breeding ground, as well as the hot springs. Kenya
